The APB clay, that contains a 0.06% wI w of iron, corresponding to the metal content in the octahedral layer of the starting bentonite, showed the lowest activity in air. As a result of the pillaring with iron doped aluminum polyhydroxy ions, the iron content of the resultant AFPB clay increases up to 2.26% wI w but the catalytic activity remains largely below that of the iron exchanged clay APB-Fe that contains only the 0.31 % wI w of metal. We can tentatively suggest from these data that the redox sites, created on the surface by thermal treatment of the metal exchanged clay, are much more accessible and effective as redox centres than the sites created in the clay octahedral layer or in the pillars structures by Al/Fe substitution. The higher reactivity of the Ru doped ARuPB clay is probably due to the well known strong oxidizing capacity of the ruthenium species. The reactivity in the propene conversion to acetone at 275°C follows the order: APB< ARuPB < AFPB « APB -Fe,AFPB -Fe the more active catalysts being by far the two iron substituted clays. The Ru doped ARuPB clay, that was the most active in the 2-propanol oxidation was found to be the least active in.the overall reaction. A possible explanation of this behaviour can be found by analyzing the catalyst behaviour in the 2-propanol to acetone conver­sion in nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. 9). The isopropanol dehydrogenation competes with the acid catalyzed dehydration to propene. The data for the propene formation for the representative APB, ARuPB and APB-Fe catalyst are reported in Fig. 9. It clearly appears from these data that the two unsubstituted clays APB and ARuPB are weaker acid catalysts. At this point, it can easily be understood why a strong oxidizing catalyst, such as ARuPB, results after all it is a mediocre catalyst of the entire reaction because of its low acidity. [29] X244 64 0304-5102(94)00064-6 10.1016/0304-5102(94)00064-6 Bifunctional catalysts from pillared clays: Vapour phase conversion of propene to acetone catalyzed by iron and ruthenium containing aluminum pillared bentonites. Maurizio Lenarda ∗ a Renzo Ganzerla a Loretta Storaro a Stefano Enzo b Roberto Zanoni c a Dipartimento di Chimica, Università di Venezia, D.D. 2137, 30123 Venice Italy b Dipartimento di Chimica Fisica, Università di Venezia, D.D. 2137, 30123 Venice, Italy c Dipartimento di Chimica, Università di Roma (La Sapienza), Piazzale A. Moro 5, 00185 Rome, Italy * Corresponding author. A natural bentonite was pillared with aluminum, aluminum—iron and aluminum—ruthenium polyoxocations. The alkali cations of some clays were successively exchanged with iron. The prepared pillared clays were characterized by X-ray diffraction, DTA, TGA, ESCA and N2 adsorption. The relative amount of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites was estimated from FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine. All the clays resulted active catalysts for the vapour phase conversion of propene to acetone in the 150–350°C temperature range. The reaction appeared to occur via acid catalyzed propene hydration to isopropanol and successive oxidative dehydrogenation of the alcohol to acetone. The reactivity of all the prepared samples was correlated to the nature and number of the redox and acid sites.
